titlestmt.subtitle: An Inventory of His Congressional Newsletters
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Kathryn A. Johnson.

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Lyda Morehouse, October 28, 1999.

change.item: Converted from EAD Version 1.0 to Version 2002 by Monica Manny Ralston, Daniel Sher, and Joyce Chapman.

did.head: OVERVIEW
did.abstract: Congressional newsletters (22 issues, mimeographed) issued by Youngdahl (Republican) while serving as Minnesota's fifth district congressman, and which reflect the principal issues of the period, especially American neutrality during the initial years of World War II.
did.physloc: See Detailed Description section for location

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHY OF OSCAR YOUNGDAHL
bioghist.p: Oscar Ferdinand Youngdahl was born on October 13, 1893 in Minneapolis, the son of John C. and Elizabeth (Johnson) Youngdahl. He graduated from Gustavus Adolphus College (St. Peter, Minn.) in 1916 and served in the U.S. Navy during World War I. He graduated from the Minnesota College of Law in 1925 and was a partner in the Minneapolis law firm of Tifft and Youngdahl from 1930 on.
Youngdahl, a Republican, was elected to Congress from Minnesota's fifth district in 1938 and served two terms. He died in Minneapolis on February 3, 1946.

scopecontent.head: SCOPE AND CONTENTS
scopecontent.p: Youngdahl's constituent newsletters reflect the principal political and economic interests of the period, especially American neutrality during the early years of World War II. There is much discussion of the proposed abolition of the Arms Embargo Act, the Lend-Lease Act, armed convoys for merchant ships, and similar issues, all of which were opposed by Youngdahl. There is also information on defense spending, welfare and public relief programs, changes in the Hatch Act, the Democratic and Republican national conventions of 1940, selective service legislation, and the issues of enemy aliens and actions against subversive activities (Dies Committee).

controlaccess.head: CATALOG HEADINGS
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the catalog of the Minnesota Historical Society. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons or places should search the catalog using these headings.
